title: $:/litClock/times/-11:00-Raymond Chandler
quote_last: in the morning, mid October, with the sun not shining and a look of hard wet rain in the clearness of the foothills. I was wearing my powder-blue suit, with dark blue shirt, tie and display handkerchief, black brogues, black wool socks with dark blue clocks on them. I was neat, clean, shaved and sober, and I didn’t care who knew it. I was everything the well-dressed private detective ought to be. I was calling on four millon dollars.

title: $:/litClock/times/-11:00-G.W.M. Reynolds
quote_first: ON the morning following the events just narrated, Mrs. Arlington was seated at breakfast in a sweet little parlour of the splendid mansion which the Earl of Warrington had taken and fitted up for her in Dover Street, Piccadilly. It was about
quote_last: ; and the Enchantress was attired in a delicious deshabillé. With her little feet upon an ottoman near the fender, and her fine form reclining in a luxurious large arm-chair, she divided her attention between her chocolate and the columns of the Morning Herald. She invariably prolonged the morning’s repast as much as possible, limply because it served to wile away the time until the hour for dressing arrived.

title: $:/litClock/times/-11:00-George Augustus Sala
quote_first: Quiet as I am, I become at
quote_last: in the Morning on every day of the week save Sunday a raving, ranting maniac – a dangerous lunatic, panting with insane desires to do, not only myself but other people, a mischief, and possessed less by hallucination than by rabies.

title: $:/litClock/times/-11:00-Mary Shelley
quote_first: We passed a few sad hours until
quote_last: , when the trial was to commence. My father and the rest of the family being obliged to attend as witnesses, I accompanied them to the court. During the whole of this wretched mockery of justice I suffered living torture.
